First, you're right (and I did mention this in another post), a full on keto diet where the body is running more on ketone oxidation than fatty acid oxidation would still be a good idea for this cancer. But not just merely reducing glucose intake some. And preferably high MCT. For most keto diets it's still >60% FAO to <40% KO. It is unclear from this user's post whether a high fat diet aggravates the condition he describes, since fats consumed orally don't enter the blood as fat, but as triglycerides... did he mean to say they rely on triglycerides? Because if not, dietary fat would not be feeding fats to prostate, or any other cells. It's the same thing, effectively. If we want to be super technical, cells can't actually absorb triglycerides because they're too big and hydrophobic to diffuse or use FATPs the way free fatty acids do. TGs are packaged as chylomicrons. And the chylomicron is broken down outside the cell by LPL to deliver FFAs across the cell membrane. What we're dealing with is FFAs from lipolysis as well as from chylomicrons from meals and an endocytosed contribution from VLDL too. That's all just a description of the systemic transport mechanisms, not the tissue/cell level metabolic mechanisms. It's all fatty acid metabolism at the cell level. Regardless of how the fats get to the cell - as FFAs, TG-bearing chylomicrons, or VLDL - they become FFAs and then 'fatty acyl-CoA' in the cytoplasm and undergo beta oxidation or are otherwise used in exactly the same way. Fatty acid metabolism is distinct from ketone metabolism, especially in terms of cancer. Fatty acids produce FADH2 when oxidized. FADH2 is responsible for delivering electrons to Complex II of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC). This is a low reactive oxygen species (ROS) route. Remember, cancer is vulnerable to oxidative stress from those ROS. High FADH2 = low stress = low vulnerability. Ketones don't produce any FADH2 when oxidized which increases cancer's ROS burden. Further to that effect, ketones are metabolized thru Complex I, which generally yields more ROS. Also, FAO produces over 6x the amount of NADH than the equivalent in KO. NADH is a reducing agent and protects the cancer from oxidative stress, and can also promote glycolysis by modulating the Krebs cycle. It also helps export citrate which if converted to itaconate will further activate HIF. And the exported citrate also promotes cytoplasmic biosynthesis of fats and their uses. The high NADH also reduces the NAD+/NADH ratio, inhibiting sirtuins which are usually a brake on cell proliferation. Another important aspect is that unlike FAO ketone oxidation depletes succinyl-CoA from the Krebs cycle. Succinyl-CoA is important for biosyntheses that cancers rely on to grow and protect themselves. It also helps stabilize and activate the hypoxia sensor HIF which is important to cancer metabolism and signaling (driving glycolysis, etc.) It also helps make heme which cancer uses to drive further cataplerosis. Further, aside from oxidative metabolism, fatty acids are also important building blocks for cell membranes, lipid rafts, lipid droplets (energy stores helping cells survive stress) and a variety of signaling molecules (eicosanoids, glycolipids, sphingolipids, etc.) and post-translational modifications (for example, palmitoylation of Wnt from palmitic acid). Ketones can't do any of that, they can only be burned. And many cancers are deficient in ketone metabolizing enzymes like OXCT1 so they can't even get much energy from them - the body is fed but the cancer is starved. There are a few cancers that thrive on ketones, but those are rare and this is not one of them. I will repeat though that most keto diets are still >60% FAO. permalink parent award report block reply Wexit-Delecto 1 points 6 days ago Thank you, very informative, and good to confirm that a good keto diet in which you're turning lots of fat into ketone bodies is hostile to most cancers. First, you're right (and I did mention this in another post), a full on keto diet where the body is running more on ketone oxidation than fatty acid oxidation would still be a good idea for this cancer. But not just merely reducing glucose intake some. And preferably high MCT. For most keto diets it's still >60% FAO to <40% KO. It is unclear from this user's post whether a high fat diet aggravates the condition he describes, since fats consumed orally don't enter the blood as fat, but as triglycerides... did he mean to say they rely on triglycerides? Because if not, dietary fat would not be feeding fats to prostate, or any other cells. It's the same thing, effectively. If we want to be super technical, cells can't actually absorb triglycerides because they're too big and hydrophobic to diffuse or use FATPs the way free fatty acids do. TGs are packaged as chylomicrons. And the chylomicron is broken down outside the cell by LPL to deliver FFAs across the cell membrane. What we're dealing with is FFAs from lipolysis as well as from chylomicrons from meals and an endocytosed contribution from VLDL too. That's all just a description of the systemic transport mechanisms, not the tissue/cell level metabolic mechanisms. It's all fatty acid metabolism at the cell level. Regardless of how the fats get to the cell - as FFAs, TG-bearing chylomicrons, or VLDL - they become FFAs and then 'fatty acyl-CoA' in the cytoplasm and undergo beta oxidation or are otherwise used in exactly the same way. Fatty acid metabolism is distinct from ketone metabolism, especially in terms of cancer. Fatty acids produce FADH2 when oxidized. FADH2 is responsible for delivering electrons to Complex II of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC). This is a low reactive oxygen species (ROS) route. Remember, cancer is vulnerable to oxidative stress from those ROS. High FADH2 = low stress = low vulnerability. Ketones don't produce any FADH2 when oxidized which increases cancer's ROS burden. Further to that effect, ketones are metabolized thru Complex I, which generally yields more ROS. Also, FAO produces over 6x the amount of NADH than the equivalent in KO. NADH is a reducing agent and protects the cancer from oxidative stress, and can also promote glycolysis by modulating the Krebs cycle. It also helps export citrate which if converted to itaconate will further activate HIF. And the exported citrate also promotes cytoplasmic biosynthesis of fats and their uses. The high NADH also reduces the NAD+/NADH ratio, inhibiting sirtuins which are usually a brake on cell proliferation. Another important aspect is that unlike FAO ketone oxidation depletes succinyl-CoA from the Krebs cycle. Succinyl-CoA is important for biosyntheses that cancers rely on to grow and protect themselves. It also helps stabilize and activate the hypoxia sensor HIF which is important to cancer metabolism and signaling (driving glycolysis, etc.) It also helps make heme which cancer uses to drive further cataplerosis. Further, aside from oxidative metabolism, fatty acids are also important building blocks for cell membranes, lipid rafts, lipid droplets (energy stores helping cells survive stress) and a variety of signaling molecules (eicosanoids, glycolipids, sphingolipids, etc.) and post-translational modifications (for example, palmitoylation of Wnt from palmitic acid). Ketones can't do any of that, they can only be burned. And many cancers are deficient in ketone metabolizing enzymes like OXCT1 so they can't even get much energy from them - the body is fed but the cancer is starved. There are a few cancers that thrive on ketones, but those are rare and this is not one of them. I will repeat though that most keto diets are still >60% FAO. permalink parent award report block reply Wexit-Delecto 1 points 6 days ago Thank you, very informative, and good to confirm that a good keto diet in which you're turning lots of fat into ketone bodies is hostile to most cancers. First, you're right (and I did mention this in another post), a full on keto diet where the body is running more on ketone oxidation than fatty acid oxidation would still be a good idea for this cancer. But not just merely reducing glucose intake some. And preferably high MCT. For most keto diets it's still >60% FAO to <40% KO. It is unclear from this user's post whether a high fat diet aggravates the condition he describes, since fats consumed orally don't enter the blood as fat, but as triglycerides... did he mean to say they rely on triglycerides? Because if not, dietary fat would not be feeding fats to prostate, or any other cells. It's the same thing, effectively. If we want to be super technical, cells can't actually absorb triglycerides because they're too big and hydrophobic to diffuse or use FATPs the way free fatty acids do. TGs are packaged as chylomicrons. And the chylomicron is broken down outside the cell by LPL to deliver FFAs across the cell membrane. What we're dealing with is FFAs from lipolysis as well as from chylomicrons from meals and an endocytosed contribution from VLDL too. That's all just a description of the systemic transport mechanisms, not the tissue/cell level metabolic mechanisms. It's all fatty acid metabolism at the cell level. Regardless of how the fats get to the cell - as FFAs, TG-bearing chylomicrons, or VLDL - they become FFAs and then 'fatty acyl-CoA' in the cytoplasm and undergo beta oxidation or are otherwise used in exactly the same way. Fatty acid metabolism is distinct from ketone metabolism, especially in terms of cancer. Fatty acids produce FADH2 when oxidized. FADH2 is responsible for delivering electrons to Complex II of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC). This is a low reactive oxygen species (ROS) route. Remember, cancer is vulnerable to oxidative stress from those ROS. High FADH2 = low stress = low vulnerability. Ketones don't produce any FADH2 when oxidized which increases cancer's ROS burden. Further to that effect, ketones are metabolized thru Complex I, which generally yields more ROS. Also, FAO produces over 6x the amount of NADH than the equivalent in KO. NADH is a reducing agent and protects the cancer from oxidative stress, and can also promote glycolysis by modulating the Krebs cycle. It also helps export citrate which if converted to itaconate will further activate HIF. And the exported citrate also promotes cytoplasmic biosynthesis of fats and their uses. The high NADH also reduces the NAD+/NADH ratio, inhibiting sirtuins which are usually a brake on cell proliferation. Another important aspect is that unlike FAO ketone oxidation depletes succinyl-CoA from the Krebs cycle. Succinyl-CoA is important for biosyntheses that cancers rely on to grow and protect themselves. It also helps stabilize and activate the hypoxia sensor HIF which is important to cancer metabolism and signaling (driving glycolysis, etc.) It also helps make heme which cancer uses to drive further cataplerosis. Further, aside from oxidative metabolism, fatty acids are also important building blocks for cell membranes, lipid rafts, lipid droplets (energy stores helping cells survive stress) and a variety of signaling molecules (eicosanoids, glycolipids, sphingolipids, etc.) and post-translational modifications (for example, palmitoylation of Wnt from palmitic acid). Ketones can't do any of that, they can only be burned. And many cancers are deficient in ketone metabolizing enzymes like OXCT1 so they can't even get much energy from them - the body is fed but the cancer is starved. There are a few cancers that thrive on ketones, but those are rare and this is not one of them. I will repeat though that most keto diets are still >60% FAO. permalink parent award report block reply Wexit-Delecto 1 points 6 days ago Thank you, very informative, and good to confirm that a good keto diet in which you're turning lots of fat into ketone bodies is hostile to most cancers.
